intro: Rubus fuscoater var. horripilus, commonly known as the blackberry bramble, is a variant of the blackberry plant native to North America. It is characterized by its thorny stems and compound leaves with serrated edges. The plant produces small, aggregate fruits that ripen to a dark purple or black color. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in woodland edges and thickets. This variant is valued for its edible berries and its role in supporting local wildlife.
